title: Garage District
subtitle: Code Without Boundaries
narrativeIntro: Welcome to ArchPatterns City, Investigator. Your journey begins in a fast-growing garage startup. The team moved quickly and ignored architectural structure. UI code touches the database directly, and small visual changes are breaking critical logic. Your mission is to bring order to the chaos.

questions.title: The Tangled Code
questions.problem: A developer was asked to change the color of a login button. To do so, he had to edit a file that also contained password validation logic and database commands. The simple visual tweak ended up corrupting user data.
questions.reason: Layered Architecture separates Presentation, Business Logic, and Data layers, preventing UI changes from impacting critical rules or data.

questions.title: The Untestable Logic
questions.problem: QA needs to test a new interest calculation rule, but the logic is embedded inside a button click handler that requires a running web server and database.
questions.reason: Isolating business logic into its own layer enables fast unit testing without external dependencies.

questions.title: Spreadsheet Chaos
questions.problem: A small company manages its 50 customers in a shared Excel file. When two salespeople save at the same time, one overwrites the other's changes.
questions.reason: Client-Server centralizes data management and controls concurrent access.

title: Commercial Center
subtitle: The One-Page Monster
narrativeIntro: Promotion granted. Now you deal with legacy corporate systems. Massive UI files directly manipulate business rules and database queries. Maintenance is risky and painful.

questions.title: The 5,000-Line File
questions.problem: A single web page contains HTML markup, CPF validation logic, and SQL statements. Any change feels dangerous.
questions.reason: MVC separates Model, View, and Controller responsibilities, reducing coupling and improving maintainability.

questions.title: The Inflexible Media Processor
questions.problem: One giant function resizes video, adds a watermark, and compresses the file. A client now wants to use only the watermark feature, but the steps cannot be separated.
questions.reason: Pipe and Filter divides processing into independent, reusable stages that can be recombined.

questions.title: The Ghost Images
questions.problem: A webpage loads 100 high-resolution images at once, causing long loading times and browser freezes.
questions.reason: A Virtual Proxy enables lazy loading, loading heavy resources only when needed.

questions.title: The Unstable Browser
questions.problem: A team wants to build a lightweight browser core but also add complex features like ad blocking and translation without compromising stability.
questions.reason: Microkernel keeps the core minimal and allows features to be added as plug-ins.

title: Industrial District
subtitle: Integration Warfare
narrativeIntro: Welcome to the industrial park. Decades-old systems attempt to communicate through fragile point-to-point integrations. One failure triggers cascading breakdowns.

questions.title: Point-to-Point Nightmare
questions.problem: HR directly calls Finance and Sales systems. If one system fails, the entire hiring process collapses.
questions.reason: SOA integrates systems through standardized services, reducing tight point-to-point coupling.

questions.title: Corporate Message Chaos
questions.problem: Dozens of systems are connected directly to each other, forming a fragile web of integrations.
questions.reason: A Message Bus standardizes communication and reduces direct system dependencies.

questions.title: The XML Barrier
questions.problem: A modern system sends JSON data, but a legacy system only accepts XML.
questions.reason: The Adapter pattern translates incompatible interfaces into a compatible format.

questions.title: The Processing Queue
questions.problem: Users must wait 30 seconds after uploading a photo while the server processes it synchronously.
questions.reason: A Broker (Message Queue) decouples request submission from background processing.

title: Digital District
subtitle: Scale or Collapse
narrativeIntro: ArchPatterns City has gone viral. Millions of simultaneous users are overwhelming the centralized architecture. Scalability is now a survival requirement.

questions.title: Overwhelmed by Success
questions.problem: During peak traffic, the entire e-commerce platform freezes because all features run as one monolithic block.
questions.reason: Microservices allow independent scaling and isolation of system components.

questions.title: The Blocking Checkout
questions.problem: If the Email service is slow, the entire purchase process is delayed because everything runs synchronously.
questions.reason: Event-Driven Architecture enables asynchronous processing and loose coupling.

questions.title: Rigid News Feed
questions.problem: The news publisher must know exactly who subscribes to each category. Adding a new category breaks the publisher logic.
questions.reason: Publish–Subscribe decouples publishers from subscribers through topics.

questions.title: Bandwidth Explosion
questions.problem: Distributing a 50GB file to one million users from a central server is financially unsustainable.
questions.reason: Peer-to-Peer distributes load across users instead of relying solely on a central server.

title: Central Tower
subtitle: Critical Coordination
narrativeIntro: You’ve reached the top. The Central Tower manages mission-critical systems. Coordination, isolation, and architectural discipline are non-negotiable.

questions.title: Air Traffic Control
questions.problem: Multiple airplanes try to coordinate landing among themselves, creating a high risk of collision.

questions.title: The Endless Transaction
questions.problem: In a distributed system, payment, stock reservation, and invoicing must occur. If invoicing fails, how can previous steps be undone without locking the entire database?
questions.reason: Saga manages distributed transactions through events and compensating actions.

questions.title: The Isolated Core
questions.problem: Business logic is tightly coupled to HTTP and SQL imports, making testing difficult.
questions.reason: Hexagonal Architecture isolates the domain core from external technologies.

questions.title: The Impossible Recognition
questions.problem: No single algorithm can accurately recognize handwritten text. Multiple algorithms must collaborate.
questions.reason: Blackboard enables multiple specialized components to cooperatively solve complex problems.
